title: Welcome
bullets: This is lesson one of CSS Training Wheels.
If you are looking for a good place for a beginner to start, you are in the right place.

title: This series is for beginners
bullets: This series was created with designers in mind who want to start the transition into front-end-development.
You do not need to be a designer to benefit from this series
Even if you are not a beginner there is always more to learn.

title: This is prep for more involved courses
bullets: Bootcamps go much better if you have an understanding of css.
Most front-end-develoment video courses expect you to know some css.
Understanding some css and how css works will make learning to code a lot easier.

title: It will be helpful to understand a little HTML
bullets: It is not necessary to be an expert in HTML.
All you need is a basic understanding of how HTML tags are structured
For example: if you understand this - <p>Some Text</p> - you should be all set.

title: CSS is really only about being able to do 2 things
bullets: 1. Creating Selectors

title: Today will be your introduction to selectors
bullets: Using the selector builder
Creating your first selector

title: What is a selector?
bullets: Before we get to selectors, we should look at the two ways css is applied to html
In-line styling and Selector styling

title: In-line styling
bullets: Applyies a style directly to a single html tag

<button style='background-color:yellow;'>OK</button>
<button>Cancel</button>

title: Selector styling
bullets: Applies style to anything that fits the description of the selector

<style>
  button{
    background-color:yellow;
  }
</style>
...
<button>OK</button>
<button>Cancel</button>

title: Selector styling can be general or specific
bullets: The more you know about selectors the more effectively you can use them.

<style>
  button:first-child{
    background-color:yellow;
  }
</style>
...
<button>OK</button>
<button>Cancel</button>
